lat: Sī haec fēcerit, gaudēbō, sī minus aequō animō feram.
eng: If he does this, I shall be glad; if not, I shall take it quietly.

lat: Nihil aliud discere est, nisi recordārī.
eng: Learning is nothing else than recollecting.

lat: Cum spē, sī nōn optimā, at aliquā tamen vīvit.
eng: He lives with some hopes, if not the highest.

lat: Iūrāvit sē, nisi victōrem, numquam reditūrum.
eng: He swore never to return, unless victorious.

lat: Sīve adhibueris medicum, sīve nōn adhibueris, convalēscēs.
eng: You will get well, whether you call in a physician or not.

lat: Seu legit, seu scrībit, nihil temporis terit.
eng: Whether he reads or writes, he wastes no time.
I do not know whether he is reading or writing.
He is either reading or writing.
Let them hate, provided they fear.
Let him remain provided he holds his tongue.
Let him remain provided he obeys me.

lat: Honestum tāle est ut, vel sī ignōrārent id hominēs, esset laudābile.
eng: Virtue is such that it would be worthy of praise even if men did not know of it.

lat: Dīc mihi quidnam factūrus fuerīs, sī eō tempore censor fuissēs.
eng: Tell me what you would have done if you had been censor at that time.

lat: Nec dubium erat quīn, sī tam paucī simul obīre omnia possent, terga datūrī hostēs fuerint.
eng: There was no doubt that, if it were possible for so few to manage everything, the enemy would have fled.

lat: Mortem mihi dēnūntiāvit pater, sī pugnāssem.
eng: My father threatened me with death if I fought.

lat: Exspectābat Caesar sī hostēs posset opprimere.
eng: Caesar was waiting in the hope of crushing the enemy.

lat: Dēbuistī enim, etiam sī falsō in suspīciōnem vēnisses, mihi ignōscere.
eng: You ought to have forgiven me, even if you had been falsely suspected.

lat: Atrōx certāmen aderat, nī Fabius rem expedīvisset.
eng: A desperate contest would have taken place, had not Fabius solved the difficulty.

lat: Ibi erat mānsūrus, sī īre nōn perrēxisset.
eng: It was there he would have stayed, had he not continued his journey.

lat: Quid enim futūrum fuit, sī rēs agitārī coepta esset?
eng: What would have happened, if once the question had begun to be discussed?

lat: Neque hostem sustinēre poterant, nī cohortēs illae sē obiēcissent.
eng: And they could not have maintained themselves against the enemy, but for those cohorts’ exposure of themselves.

lat: Virginēs sī effūgissent, implētūrae urbem tumultū erant.
eng: Had the maidens escaped, they would have spread disorder through the whole city.

lat: Praeclārē vīcerāmus, nisi hostēs sē recēpissent.
eng: We should have won a splendid victory, had not the enemy retreated.

lat: Sī in hōc errāvī, id mihi velim ignōscās.
eng: If I have blundered in this, I beg you to forgive me.

lat: Circumfunduntur hostēs sī quem aditum reperīre possent.
eng: The enemy swarm round, in hopes of finding some means of approach.

lat: Praemium prōposuit, sī quis ducem interfēcisset.
eng: He offered a prize in case any one should kill the leader.

lat: Nūntium ad tē mīsī, sī forte nōn audīssēs.
eng: I sent you a messenger, in case you had not heard.

lat: Nōn recūsāvit quōminus vel extrēmō spīritū, sī quam opem reī pūblicae ferre posset, experīrētur.
eng: He did not flinch from trying even with his latest breath whether he could not give some aid to his country

lat: Etiamsī nōn adiuvēs, haec facere possim.
eng: Even if you were not to help, I would be able to do this.

lat: Vēra loquī, etsī meum ingenium nōn monēret, necessitās cōgit.
eng: Even if my disposition did not bid me, necessity compels me to speak the truth.

lat: Etsī mōns Cevenna iter impediēbat, tamen ad fīnēs Arvernōrum pervēnit.
eng: Although the Cevennes were in the way of his march, he reached the territory of the Arverni.

lat: Rōmānī quamquam itinere et aestū fessī erant, tamen obviam hostibus prōcēdunt.
eng: Though the Romans were fatigued with the march and the heat, yet they advanced to meet the enemy.

lat: Quamvīs sit magna exspectātiō, tamen eam vincēs.
eng: Although expectations are great, you will surpass them.

lat: Licet undique perīcula impendeant, tamen subībō.
eng: Though dangers threaten me on every side, I will face them.

lat: Homō optimus ille quidem, sed interdum peccat; ita homō optimus est ut interdum peccet; sit homō ille optimus, tamen interdum peccat.
eng: Though he is an excellent man, he does wrong sometimes.

lat: Rēs sānē difficilis, sed tamen investīganda.
eng: Though a difficult question, yet still one that demands investigation.

lat: Hōc crīmine absolūtus, fūrtī tamen condemnātus est.
eng: Though acquitted on this charge he was found guilty of theft.

lat: Hostēs, quoniam iam nox erat, domum discessērunt.
eng: The enemy, since it was now night, departed homewards.

lat: Idcircō ad tē scrībō quod mē id, facere iussistī.
eng: The reason of my writing is that you told me to do so.
They departed because (as they alleged) they were tired.

lat: Rēx cīvibus odiō erat, quod lēgēs violāvisset.
eng: The king was hated by his subjects, because he had broken the law.
He is angry with me because (as he says) I have neglected him.

lat: Haec fēcī, nōn quō tuī mē taedeat sed quod abīre cupiō.
eng: I did this, not that I am tired of you, but because I am anxious to depart.

lat: Cum sīs mortālis, quae mortālia sunt, cūrā.
eng: Since you are mortal, look to the things that are mortal.

lat: Magnum est quod victor victīs pepercit.
eng: It is no small thing that he spared the vanquished when victorious.
Your coming was very fortunate.
There is the additional reason that he is not at home.

lat: Adde quod īdem nōn hōram tēcum esse potes.
eng: Besides, you cannot keep your own company for an hour.

lat: Omittō illud, quod rēgem patriamque prōdidit.
eng: I pass over the fact of his having betrayed his king and country.

lat: Gaudē quod spectant oculī tē mīlle loquentem.
eng: Rejoice that a thousand eyes behold you as you speak.

lat: Hōc proestāmus maximē ferīs, quod loquimur.
eng: We excel beasts most in this respect, that we speak.
I mean the fact of your having betrayed your country.

lat: He was punished as he deserved.
eng: Perinde ac meritus est, poenās persolvit.

lat: He was punished as though he had deserved it.
eng: Perinde ac sī merilus esset, poenās persolvit.

lat: Tanta est tempestās, quantam numquam anteā vīdī.
eng: The storm is greater than I ever saw before, or is unparalleled in my experience.

lat: Perinde ac meritus est, poenās persolvit.
eng: He was punished as he deserved.
He paid the penalty which he merited.
He was punished in accordance with his guilt.

lat: Aliter tum locūtus es, aliter tē geris hodiē.
eng: Your behaviour today is most inconsistent with your language at that time.

lat: Ut fortasse honestum est hoc, sīc parum ūtile.
eng: Though this is perhaps right, yet it is scarcely expedient.
May I live so far only as I love you (i.e. may I die if I do not love you).

lat: Tum rēx, ut erat nātūrā benignus, omnibus veniam dedit.
eng: Thereupon the king, in accordance with the kindness of his nature, forgave them all.

lat: Magnus pavor, ut in rē imprōvīsā, fuit.
eng: The panic was great, as was natural in so unexpected an occurrence.

lat: Satis intrepidē, ut in rē imprōvīsā, sē gessit.
eng: He showed considerable presence of mind, considering the unexpected nature of the occurrence

lat: Nec ultrā saeviit quam satis erat.
eng: Nor did he show more severity than was necessary.

lat: Tūtior est certa pāx quam spērāta victōria.
eng: A definite peace is safer than an anticipated victory.
The pestilence was more alarming than fatal.

lat: Hoc bellum fortius quam fēlīcius gessistis.
eng: You have carried on this war with more courage than good fortune.

lat: Tam timidus hodiē est quam tum fuit audāx.
eng: He is as cowardly today as he was then bold.

lat: Ita sē gessit quasi cōnsul esset.
eng: He behaved as though he were consul.

lat: Eius negōtium sīc velim suscipiās, ut sī esset rēs me.
eng: I wish you would undertake his business just as if it were my affair.
I love him as though I were his father.
I hate him as a public enemy.

lat: Ē corpore, velut ē carcere, ēvolat animus.
eng: The soul flies forth from the prison-house of the body.

lat: Nēve tē obruī, tamquam flūctū, sīc magnitūdine negōtiī, sinas.
eng: Do not suffer yourself to be overwhelmed by the tide of business.
Fight to the death rather than be a slave.

lat: Nōs potius hostem aggrediāmur quam ipsī cum prōpulsēmus.
eng: Let us take an aggressive, rather than a merely defensive, attitude.

lat: Īsocratēs maiōre ingeniō est quam ut cum Lysiā comparētur.
eng: Isocrates is too great a genius to be compared with Lysias.

lat: Nihil ultrā commōtus est quam ut abīre eōs iubēret.
eng: He was only so far moved as to bid them depart.

lat: Quō dēlictum maius est, eō poena est tardior.
eng: The greater the fault, the slower the punishment.

lat: Quī bonī sunt, īdem sunt beātī.
eng: Those who are good are also happy.

lat: Omnia, quae pater suus relīquissset, mihi lēgāvit.
eng: He bequeathed to me everything which his father had left.

lat: Frātrem tuum, virum praeclārissimum, valdē admīror, quī brevī cōnsul fīet.
eng: I profoundly admire your distinguished brother who will soon be made consul.

lat: Equitēs in castrīs relīquit, quī ērumperent.

lat: Equitēs in castrīs relīquit, quī ērūpērunt.
eng: He left cavalry behind in the camp, who made a charge.

lat: Habētis eum cōnsulem quī pārēre vestrīs dēcrētīs nōn dubitet.
eng: You have a consul such as does not hesitate to obey your decrees.

lat: Ea est Rōmāna gēns quae victa quiēscere nesciat.
eng: The race of Romans is one that knows not how to rest under defeat.

lat: Nihil est quod magis deceat quam cōnstantia.
eng: Nothing is more becoming than consistency.

lat: Sōlus es, Caesar, cuius in victōriā ceciderit nēmō.
eng: You are the only one, Caesar, in whose victory no one has fallen.

lat: Quotus quisque invenītur quī haec facere audeat.

lat: Mē miserum, quī haec nōn vīderim!

lat: Tum ille, quī homō esset iūstissimus, etc.

lat: Tum Caesar, quī hoc intellegeret, tamen redīre statuit.

lat: Eum semper prō amīcō habuī, quippe quem scīrem meī esse amantissimum.

lat: Nec cōnsul, ut quī id ipsum quaesīvisset, moram certāminī fēcit.
